task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab's current role and employment history at Amazon
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. He joined Amazon in October 2022 as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on the company's latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Before his tenure at Amazon, Dr. Khaledi Nasab earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. His research aimed to understand the functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Following his doctoral studies, he worked at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery, collaborating with Dr. Peter Tass on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. He also joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions in 2022, CODA was unable to secure the necessary funding and had to close its doors. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional roles, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academia, publishing research on topics such as the depolarization of echo chambers through random dynamical nudges. He has also contributed to the Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, serving as the editor for the Brain Development section. This collaborative work received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine by the Association of American Publishers. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab's diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and AI underscores his commitment to advancing scientific understanding and developing innovative solutions in the field of artificial intelligence.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_2.query_used: Search Google Scholar and academic databases for research papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI/machine learning
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher affiliated with Amazon, specializing in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His notable contributions include:

- **"Evaluation of artificial intelligence techniques in disease diagnosis and prediction"**: This study assesses various AI methods for diagnosing and predicting diseases, highlighting their effectiveness and potential applications. ([europepmc.org](https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/pmc9885935?utm_source=openai))

- **"Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neuronal Networks by Double-Random Coordinated Reset Stimulation"**: This research explores the impact of coordinated reset stimulation on neuronal networks, offering insights into neural desynchronization mechanisms. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

- **"Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)"**: This paper investigates the control of optical bistability and multistability using DDRs, contributing to advancements in optical communication technologies. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These works reflect Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary approach, integrating machine learning with neuroscience and optical physics to address complex challenges.

citations.title: Evaluation of artificial intelligence techniques in disease diagnosis and prediction - Abstract - Europe PMC

task_3.query_used: Search GitHub and technical repositories for code contributions by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. His professional journey includes a Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, followed by research positions at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery and a role at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup. In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his technical contributions, there is no publicly available information indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab has code repositories or contributions on GitHub. His professional focus appears to be on research and development in physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, rather than on open-source software development.

task_4.query_used: Search Amazon's official research publications and blog posts mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data: Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon. He holds a Ph.D. in physics and has a background in neuroscience, which has led him to specialize in artificial intelligence. Before joining Amazon, he was a postdoctoral researcher at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery and later worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup. In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on a new generative AI product. He has also been appointed as an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. In 2023, he published a piece in Science Magazine titled "I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD," reflecting on the challenges of financing graduate education. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_5.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for conference papers by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
I searched the IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library databases for conference papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab. While I couldn't locate specific conference papers by this author in these databases, I found several publications authored by Ali Khaledi-Nasab in other journals and conferences.

For instance, in 2016, Ali Khaledi-Nasab co-authored a paper titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the *Journal of Experimental Nanoscience*. This study explores the use of potato extract as a green reducing agent and stabilizer in the synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Another notable work is "Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer," co-authored by Ali Khaledi-Nasab and published as an arXiv preprint in 2012. This research investigates the optical properties of InAs/GaAs quantum dots, focusing on the effects of size and the presence of a wetting layer. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to studies on the coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances, published in *Optics Communications* in 2014. This paper examines the mechanisms behind optical bistability and multistability in semiconductor systems, with potential applications in optical switching and memory devices. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Ali Khaledi-Nasab's contributions to fields such as nanotechnology, quantum optics, and nonlinear dynamics.

task_6.query_used: Search ResearchGate and ORCID profiles for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic research history
task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research has spanned various areas, including the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons, the synthesis of nanoparticles, and the development of control systems for autonomous underwater vehicles.

In 2019, as a doctoral student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award. This grant supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston, where he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research focused on understanding the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies, such as those found in muscle spindles and pain receptors. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, he delivered a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics, discussing "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." This work utilized biophysical models to study the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Beyond his work in physics, Khaledi Nasab has contributed to the field of nanotechnology. He co-authored a 2016 paper titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabilizer in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the Journal of Experimental Nanoscience. This study explored environmentally friendly methods for synthesizing zinc oxide nanoparticles using potato extract. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2019, he co-authored a paper on the "Adaptive nonlinear control of an autonomous underwater vehicle," published in the Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control. This research focused on developing robust control systems for autonomous underwater vehicles, addressing challenges such as trajectory tracking and obstacle avoidance. ([journals.sagepub.com](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0142331218823869?utm_source=openai))

Khaledi Nasab has also engaged in discussions on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in Science magazine, where he shared his experiences and the difficulties encountered by international students during the Trump administration's first travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his academic profiles, Khaledi Nasab has a Google Scholar profile, which lists his publications and citation metrics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai)) However, specific profiles on ResearchGate and ORCID were not found in the available sources.

task_7.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in relation to Amazon or AI research
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a background in machine learning, artificial intelligence, and computational neuroscience. He has been affiliated with Amazon, as indicated by his verified email address at amazon.com. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In addition to his industry experience, Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to academic research. Notably, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores methods to mitigate the formation of echo chambers in social networks. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079v2?utm_source=openai))

Furthermore, Khaledi-Nasab has shared insights on professional development through a Medium article titled "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," offering advice on navigating job interviews and career growth. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

While there are no specific news articles or press releases linking Khaledi-Nasab to Amazon's AI research, his academic and professional endeavors suggest a strong involvement in the field of artificial intelligence.

task_8.query_used: Search patent databases (USPTO, Google Patents) for inventions filed by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_8.data:
After searching the USPTO and Google Patents databases, I found a patent associated with an inventor named Ali Khalajmehrabadi:

- **Patent Number**: 11105932
- **Title**: Method and system for detecting and mitigating time synchronization attacks of global positioning system (GPS) receivers
- **Abstract**: This patent describes a system and method for detecting and estimating time synchronization attacks (TSAs) on GPS receivers. The solution provides comprehensive countermeasures against various types of TSAs, allowing GPS receivers to continue normal operation without interrupting network services.
- **Filed**: December 20, 2018
- **Issued**: August 31, 2021
- **Assignee**: Board of Regents, The University of Texas System
- **Inventors**: Ali Khalajmehrabadi, Nikolaos Gatsis, David Akopian, Ahmad Fayez Taha

You can view the full patent details here: ([patents.justia.com](https://patents.justia.com/assignee/board-of?page=287&utm_source=openai))

Please note that while the name "Ali Khalajmehrabadi" is similar to "Ali Khaledi Nasab," they may refer to different individuals. No patents were found under the name "Ali Khaledi Nasab" in the available databases.

citations.title: Patents Assigned to Board of - Justia Patents Search

task_10.query_used: Search university websites and faculty directories for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic affiliations
task_10.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon in Seattle, Washington. He earned his Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, where he conducted research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly focusing on sensory neurons with tree-like structures. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

After completing his doctoral studies, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's School of Medicine as a researcher in the Department of Neurosurgery. There, he collaborated on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions, the company ceased operations in 2022. Following this, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In 2024, he was appointed as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab's research interests encompass nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He is passionate about leveraging his expertise to advance AI and deepen our understanding of complex systems. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_11.query_used: Search Iranian academic institutions and research centers for publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is an academic affiliated with Amazon, specializing in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. His research has been published in various scientific journals and preprints.

One of his notable works is the 2016 paper titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabilizer in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," co-authored with F. Buazar, M. Bavi, F. Kroushawi, and M. Halvani. This study explores the use of potato extract in the green synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles, highlighting its potential as a reducing and stabilizing agent. The paper has been cited 129 times, indicating its impact in the field. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Another significant contribution is the 2012 preprint "Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer," co-authored with M. Sabaeian. This research investigates the optical properties of quantum dots, focusing on the effects of size and the presence of a wetting layer, which are crucial for applications in optoelectronics. The preprint has garnered 97 citations. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab co-authored a 2016 paper titled "Facile one-pot phytosynthesis of magnetic nanoparticles using potato extract and their catalytic activity," with F. Buazar, M.H. Baghlani-Nejazd, M. Badri, and M. Kashisaz. This study presents a simple method for synthesizing magnetic nanoparticles using potato extract, emphasizing their catalytic properties. The paper has been cited 90 times. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications reflect Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary research interests, contributing to advancements in nanotechnology, quantum physics, and computational neuroscience.

task_12.data:
After reviewing available information, I found that Ali Khaledi Nasab has contributed to professional discussions in the following ways:

**Academic Publications:**
- In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine. The piece discusses the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the 2017 travel ban, emphasizing the need for institutional support. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

**Research Contributions:**
- He has been involved in research related to software engineering. For instance, he co-authored a paper titled "A Qualitative Study of Architectural Design Issues in DevOps," which examines architectural challenges in DevOps environments. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.06705?utm_source=openai))

**Online Presence:**
- On Stack Exchange, a user named "Ali" with a profile indicating a background in quantum computation and information has been active for over 11 years. This user has a reputation of 101 and has participated in various communities, including Physics, Mathematics, and Software Engineering. ([softwareengineering.stackexchange.com](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/users/91388/ali?utm_source=openai))

However, there is no direct evidence linking this Stack Exchange user to Ali Khaledi Nasab. Additionally, no relevant posts by him were found on Twitter or Reddit.

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 12, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on generative AI.  He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has prior experience in research and the biotech industry.  No red flags were identified in the provided OSINT sources.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus (since 2024) working on generative AI products.
* Previously worked at Amazon as a Research Scientist in the AWS network capacity team (2022-2024).
* Postdoctoral researcher at Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Neurosurgery.
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup.
* Holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks.


**Business & Financial Activity**

* No business ownership or financial activities were identified in the provided sources.


**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No legal or criminal mentions were found.


**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019.
* Presented research at the APS annual meeting in Boston.
* Authored an article "Standing up to fear" in *Science* magazine in 2017, addressing challenges faced by international students.
* Authored and co-authored research papers in various domains, including:
    * Evaluation of artificial intelligence techniques in disease diagnosis and prediction.
    * Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge.
    * A Qualitative Study of Architectural Design Issues in DevOps.
    * Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles.
    * Adaptive nonlinear control of an autonomous underwater vehicle (co-author, different last name, possible relative).
* Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017.


**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)).
* Active on Medium ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai)).
* Presence on Stack Overflow ([softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/users/91388/ali](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/users/91388/ali?utm_source=openai)).
* Google Scholar profile ([scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai]).
* Academia.edu profile ([www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai)).


**Other Notable Mentions**

*  No other notable mentions were found in the provided sources.



### Risk Profile

Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**.  His background consists of academic achievements, professional experience at reputable institutions, and contributions to research.  No negative information was found regarding his legal, financial, or professional conduct.

flagged_issues: The report mentions 'Adaptive nonlinear control of an autonomous underwater vehicle' as authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab, but the retrieval evidence indicates this was co-authored with a different last name (Fahimeh S Tabataba'i-Nasab), suggesting this may be a different person or a relative
The report could benefit from more specific citations to track information provenance
Some minor chronological inconsistencies could be clarified (e.g., the transition from Stanford to CODA to Amazon)
The patent mentioned in retrieval evidence (Ali Khalajmehrabadi) is correctly not included in the report as it appears to be a different person
Missing investigation areas include: personal social media presence beyond professional platforms, any speaking engagements or conference presentations beyond the mentioned APS conference
judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 12, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on generative AI products¹. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has prior experience in research at Stanford University School of Medicine and the biotech industry. No red flags were identified in the provided OSINT sources.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus (since 2024) working on generative AI products¹
* Previously worked at Amazon as a Research Scientist in the AWS network capacity team (2022-2024)¹
* Postdoctoral researcher at Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Neurosurgery, working with Dr. Peter Tass on stimulation methods for neurological disorders¹
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on epilepsy treatments (company closed in 2022 due to funding issues)¹
* Holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks²
* Appointed as adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University⁴

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No business ownership or financial activities were identified in the provided sources
* No SEC filings or corporate directory listings found⁹

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No legal or criminal mentions were found

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019²
* Presented research "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons" at the APS annual meeting in Boston⁶
* Authored "Standing up to fear" in *Science* magazine in 2017, addressing challenges faced by international students⁶⁹
* Published "I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD" in *Science* magazine in 2023⁴
* Contributed to the Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health as editor for the Brain Development section (received 2024 PROSE Award)¹
* Authored and co-authored research papers including:
    * "Evaluation of artificial intelligence techniques in disease diagnosis and prediction"²
    * "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge"⁷
    * "A Qualitative Study of Architectural Design Issues in DevOps"¹²
    * "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles"⁵⁶
    * "Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer"⁵
    * "Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)"²⁵
* Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 on "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks"⁶

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com))¹³⁴
* Active on Medium with professional development content¹²
* Presence on Stack Overflow (user profile indicates 11+ years activity, though direct attribution uncertain)¹²
* Google Scholar profile with verified Amazon email²⁵⁶⁷
* Academia.edu profile⁶⁹

**Other Notable Mentions**

* Note: A paper on "Adaptive nonlinear control of an autonomous underwater vehicle" was co-authored by Fahimeh S Tabataba'i-Nasab, which may indicate a family relation but is not confirmed to be the same person⁶

### Risk Profile

Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. His background consists of legitimate academic achievements, professional experience at reputable institutions (Ohio University, Stanford, Amazon), and contributions to peer-reviewed research. No negative information was found regarding his legal, financial, or professional conduct.

### Missing Investigation Areas

* Personal social media accounts (Facebook, Instagram, personal Twitter)
* Conference presentations beyond the 2019 APS meeting
* Any consulting work or advisory positions
* Professional references or recommendations
* Media interviews or podcast appearances

---

**Citations:**

2. scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ - Google Scholar profile
3. ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference
4. alikhaledi.com - Science Magazine publication reference

task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab's current role and employment history at Amazon
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. He joined Amazon in October 2022 as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on the company's latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Before his tenure at Amazon, Dr. Khaledi Nasab earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. His research aimed to understand the functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Following his doctoral studies, he worked at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery, collaborating with Dr. Peter Tass on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. He also joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions in 2022, CODA was unable to secure the necessary funding and had to close its doors. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional roles, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academia, publishing research on topics such as the depolarization of echo chambers through random dynamical nudges. He has also contributed to the Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, serving as the editor for the Brain Development section. This collaborative work received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine by the Association of American Publishers. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab's diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and AI underscores his commitment to advancing scientific understanding and developing innovative solutions in the field of artificial intelligence.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_2.query_used: Search Google Scholar and academic databases for research papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI/machine learning
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher affiliated with Amazon, specializing in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His notable contributions include:

- **"Evaluation of artificial intelligence techniques in disease diagnosis and prediction"**: This study assesses various AI methods for diagnosing and predicting diseases, highlighting their effectiveness and potential applications. ([europepmc.org](https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/pmc9885935?utm_source=openai))

- **"Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neuronal Networks by Double-Random Coordinated Reset Stimulation"**: This research explores the impact of coordinated reset stimulation on neuronal networks, offering insights into neural desynchronization mechanisms. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

- **"Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)"**: This paper investigates the control of optical bistability and multistability using DDRs, contributing to advancements in optical communication technologies. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These works reflect Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary approach, integrating machine learning with neuroscience and optical physics to address complex challenges.

citations.title: Evaluation of artificial intelligence techniques in disease diagnosis and prediction - Abstract - Europe PMC

task_3.query_used: Search GitHub and technical repositories for code contributions by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. His professional journey includes a Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, followed by research positions at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery and a role at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup. In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his technical contributions, there is no publicly available information indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab has code repositories or contributions on GitHub. His professional focus appears to be on research and development in physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, rather than on open-source software development.

task_4.query_used: Search Amazon's official research publications and blog posts mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data: Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon. He holds a Ph.D. in physics and has a background in neuroscience, which has led him to specialize in artificial intelligence. Before joining Amazon, he was a postdoctoral researcher at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery and later worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup. In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on a new generative AI product. He has also been appointed as an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. In 2023, he published a piece in Science Magazine titled "I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD," reflecting on the challenges of financing graduate education. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_5.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for conference papers by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
I searched the IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library databases for conference papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab. While I couldn't locate specific conference papers by this author in these databases, I found several publications authored by Ali Khaledi-Nasab in other journals and conferences.

For instance, in 2016, Ali Khaledi-Nasab co-authored a paper titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the *Journal of Experimental Nanoscience*. This study explores the use of potato extract as a green reducing agent and stabilizer in the synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Another notable work is "Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer," co-authored by Ali Khaledi-Nasab and published as an arXiv preprint in 2012. This research investigates the optical properties of InAs/GaAs quantum dots, focusing on the effects of size and the presence of a wetting layer. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to studies on the coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances, published in *Optics Communications* in 2014. This paper examines the mechanisms behind optical bistability and multistability in semiconductor systems, with potential applications in optical switching and memory devices. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Ali Khaledi-Nasab's contributions to fields such as nanotechnology, quantum optics, and nonlinear dynamics.

task_6.query_used: Search ResearchGate and ORCID profiles for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic research history
task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research has spanned various areas, including the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons, the synthesis of nanoparticles, and the development of control systems for autonomous underwater vehicles.

In 2019, as a doctoral student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award. This grant supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston, where he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research focused on understanding the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies, such as those found in muscle spindles and pain receptors. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, he delivered a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics, discussing "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." This work utilized biophysical models to study the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Beyond his work in physics, Khaledi Nasab has contributed to the field of nanotechnology. He co-authored a 2016 paper titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabilizer in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the Journal of Experimental Nanoscience. This study explored environmentally friendly methods for synthesizing zinc oxide nanoparticles using potato extract. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2019, he co-authored a paper on the "Adaptive nonlinear control of an autonomous underwater vehicle," published in the Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control. This research focused on developing robust control systems for autonomous underwater vehicles, addressing challenges such as trajectory tracking and obstacle avoidance. ([journals.sagepub.com](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0142331218823869?utm_source=openai))

Khaledi Nasab has also engaged in discussions on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in Science magazine, where he shared his experiences and the difficulties encountered by international students during the Trump administration's first travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his academic profiles, Khaledi Nasab has a Google Scholar profile, which lists his publications and citation metrics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai)) However, specific profiles on ResearchGate and ORCID were not found in the available sources.

Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_7.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in relation to Amazon or AI research
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a background in machine learning, artificial intelligence, and computational neuroscience. He has been affiliated with Amazon, as indicated by his verified email address at amazon.com. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In addition to his industry experience, Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to academic research. Notably, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores methods to mitigate the formation of echo chambers in social networks. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079v2?utm_source=openai))

Furthermore, Khaledi-Nasab has shared insights on professional development through a Medium article titled "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," offering advice on navigating job interviews and career growth. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

While there are no specific news articles or press releases linking Khaledi-Nasab to Amazon's AI research, his academic and professional endeavors suggest a strong involvement in the field of artificial intelligence.

citations.title: [2101.04079v2] Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge
An Introduction to a successful job interview | by Ali Khaledi Nasab | Medium

task_8.query_used: Search patent databases (USPTO, Google Patents) for inventions filed by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_8.data:
After searching the USPTO and Google Patents databases, I found a patent associated with an inventor named Ali Khalajmehrabadi:

- **Patent Number**: 11105932
- **Title**: Method and system for detecting and mitigating time synchronization attacks of global positioning system (GPS) receivers
- **Abstract**: This patent describes a system and method for detecting and estimating time synchronization attacks (TSAs) on GPS receivers. The solution provides comprehensive countermeasures against various types of TSAs, allowing GPS receivers to continue normal operation without interrupting network services.
- **Filed**: December 20, 2018
- **Issued**: August 31, 2021
- **Assignee**: Board of Regents, The University of Texas System
- **Inventors**: Ali Khalajmehrabadi, Nikolaos Gatsis, David Akopian, Ahmad Fayez Taha

You can view the full patent details here: ([patents.justia.com](https://patents.justia.com/assignee/board-of?page=287&utm_source=openai))

Please note that while the name "Ali Khalajmehrabadi" is similar to "Ali Khaledi Nasab," they may refer to different individuals. No patents were found under the name "Ali Khaledi Nasab" in the available databases.

citations.title: Patents Assigned to Board of - Justia Patents Search

task_9.query_used: Search corporate directories and SEC filings for business connections to Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_9.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a doctoral candidate in physics and astronomy at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio. In April 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine, where he discussed the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the Trump administration's travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding corporate affiliations or SEC filings, there is no publicly available information linking Ali Khaledi Nasab to any business entities or financial activities. His professional profile primarily focuses on his academic pursuits in the field of physics and astronomy.

task_12.query_used: Search Twitter, Reddit, and Stack Overflow for professional discussions or posts by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_12.data:
After reviewing available information, I found that Ali Khaledi Nasab has contributed to professional discussions in the following ways:

**Academic Publications:**
- In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine. The piece discusses the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the 2017 travel ban, emphasizing the need for institutional support. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

**Research Contributions:**
- He has been involved in research related to software engineering. For instance, he co-authored a paper titled "A Qualitative Study of Architectural Design Issues in DevOps," which examines architectural challenges in DevOps environments. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.06705?utm_source=openai))

**Online Presence:**
- On Stack Exchange, a user named "Ali" with a profile indicating a background in quantum computation and information has been active for over 11 years. This user has a reputation of 101 and has participated in various communities, including Physics, Mathematics, and Software Engineering. ([softwareengineering.stackexchange.com](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/users/91388/ali?utm_source=openai))

However, there is no direct evidence linking this Stack Exchange user to Ali Khaledi Nasab. Additionally, no relevant posts by him were found on Twitter or Reddit.
